feed.title: Talking Title IX and College Sports
feed.subtitle: As a college athlete, do you know your rights under Title IX, the law that bars discrimination on the basis of gender? As someone who cares about fairness in college sports, do you know what Title IX requires and what it doesn’t require when it is applied to athletics? Join Dr. Ellen J. Staurowsky, her students, and leading experts as we talk about all things Title IX and college sports. An Ithaca College Park School of Communications and High Tops Media Podcast

entry.title: College Athletes Compensation Issues: The Current Status of In re: College Athlete NIL Litigation - Season 2 Episode 3

link.title: College Athletes Compensation Issues: The Current Status of In re: College Athlete NIL Litigation - Season 2 Episode 3

entry.content:
In a case currently pending in the US District Court in Northern California before Judge Claudia Wilkens, multiple college athletes have challenged the NCAA and the Power Five Conferences for retroactive compensation they were denied as a result of the NCAA’s restrictive compensation rules and share of revenue produced from broadcast rights. This case is being watched closely because of what a favorable ruling would mean for college athletes and how this might affect the business of college sport moving forward. To help us break down this case and talk through these arguments that are being presented on both sides, today we have Matt Netti, an associate with Nixon Peabody who focuses on employment counseling, representing employers in litigation and labor negotiations, and a wide variety of general labor and employment matters.

Host: Dr. Ellen Staurowsky

Guest: Matt Netti (Associate with Nixon Peabody, Ithaca College Alumni)

entry.title: Pregnancy Discrimination and College Sports After 50 Years of Title IX - Season 2 Episode 2

link.title: Pregnancy Discrimination and College Sports After 50 Years of Title IX - Season 2 Episode 2

entry.content:
In this episode, we focus on an often under-reported but incredibly important part of the lives of college athletes, that being the group of women athletes who are expectant mothers and women and men athletes who are parents. To help us talk through these things today and to understand the dynamics around the access college athletes have to information about their rights relative to pregnancy and parenting under Title IX and NCAA bylaws as well as policy, we have two special guests, Dr. David McArdle and Dr. Sylvia de Mars.

Host: Dr. Ellen Staurowsky

Guests: Dr. David McArdle (Senior Lecturer in the School of Law at Stirling University, Scotland) & Dr. Sylvia de Mars (Reader in Transnational Public Law at Newcastle University School of Law in England)

entry.title: The Demand IX Campaign: Empowering the Next Generation of Title IX Advocates - Season 2 Episode 1

link.title: The Demand IX Campaign: Empowering the Next Generation of Title IX Advocates - Season 2 Episode 1

entry.title: A Conversation About Trans Inclusion in Sport in Title IX’s 50th Anniversary Year - Season 1 Episode 12

link.title: A Conversation About Trans Inclusion in Sport in Title IX’s 50th Anniversary Year - Season 1 Episode 12

entry.content:
In this episode we examined issues related to ongoing conversations regarding transgender athlete experience in sport, efforts to make sport a more inclusive space for transgender athletes, and increasing efforts on the part of state entities to regulate and control how, when, and under what circumstances transgender athletes compete in sport.

Panelists: Anna Baeth, Ph.D. (she/her), critical feminist scholar and a cultural studies practitioner of sport. Director of Research, Athlete Ally; assistant field hockey coach, Mount Holyoke College

August Donato, IC ’26, Men’s Rugby Team

Vikki Krane, Ph.D., (they/them), Professor, Human Movement, Sport, and Leisure Studies, Bowling Green State University and editor, Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Sport: Queer Inquiries

Luca Maurer, Interim Executive Director, Student Equity and Belonging, and Director, Center for LGBT Education, Outreach & Service and will soon serve as Executive Director of Student Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging

entry.title: Reproductive Rights of Women Athletes in Title IX’s 50th Anniversary Year and Post-Dobbs - Season 1 Episode 11

link.title: Reproductive Rights of Women Athletes in Title IX’s 50th Anniversary Year and Post-Dobbs - Season 1 Episode 11

entry.content:
In this episode we examined issues related to the reproductive rights of women athletes beginning with a brief historical perspective on the tensions around perceived risks and threats that sports participation posed for women in the late 19th and 20th centuries and issues women athletes face in the 21st century including women athletes rights under Title IX in terms of pregnancy and parenting; problematic issues associated with tracking the menstrual cycles of women athletes; and how access to bodily autonomy and reproductive freedom impact women athletes and women’s lives in general.

Panelists: Leila Abolfazli, J.D., Director of National Strategy on Abortion Rights, National Women’s Law Center

Bayliss Fiddiman, J.D., Director of Educational Equity, Senior Counsel, National Women’s Law Center

Lindsey Darvin, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Syracuse University

Jaime Schultz, Ph.D., Sport Historian, Professor, The Pennsylvania State University

Elizabeth Sorensen, Ph.D., R.N., professor, Wright State University and co-author, NCAA Pregnancy and Parenting

entry.title: Title IX Through the Lens of Gender and Race Intersectionality: Not All Women Athletes Benefit Equally - Season 1 Episode 10

link.title: Title IX Through the Lens of Gender and Race Intersectionality: Not All Women Athletes Benefit Equally - Season 1 Episode 10

entry.content:
The focus of this episode was on the barriers to participation and work that Black women encounter in the U.S. college sport system, the effects of racial clustering, the experiences of Black women athletes, coaches, and athletics administrators, and steps to promote gender and racial equity in the college sport space.

Moderator: Dr. Ellen J. Staurowsky

Panelists: Kirsten Hextrum, Ph.D., Assistant Professor of Language, Culture, and Society; Graduate Faculty in Women, Gender, & Sexuality Studies; and Director of the College Student Services Administration Program, Oregon State University

Katelyn Hutchison, IC SPME & MBA ‘22, Master’s Candidate – Sport Leadership and Member, Women’s Track & Field, University of Kentucky

Joyce Olushola Ogunrinde, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Kinesiology-Sport Management, University of Houston

F. Michelle Richardson, Ph.D., Associate Professor, Sport Management, Coppin State & President, North American Society for the Sociology of Sport

Erienne Roberts, J.D., Deputy Athletics Director, Ithaca College

entry.title: The Future of Women’s Sports Media Coverage - Season 1 Episode 9

link.title: The Future of Women’s Sports Media Coverage - Season 1 Episode 9

entry.content:
In this episode, we explored barriers to women’s sports media coverage, new ways of thinking about women’s sports media coverage, how the lack of sports media coverage affects women’s sports, and how to unlock opportunities for greater and better sports media coverage of women’s sports.

Moderator: Arla Davis (SPME ‘23)

Panelists: Carol Stiff, former VP of Programming and Acquisitions, ESPN; President of the Board of Directors, Women’s Basketball Hall of Fame; and Chair, Women’s Sports Network Board of Advisors

Deborah Stroman, Ph.D., CLU, Professor University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (Director, Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in Research Program and Faculty Advisor, Carolina Sport Business Club); Entrepreneur, Center of Sport Business and Analytics

Dunja Antunovic, Ph.D., Assistant Professor, Sport Sociology, University of Minnesota

entry.title: Women and Men College Athletes Losing Out on Their Fair Share of Opportunities and Scholarships - Season 1 Episode 8

link.title: Women and Men College Athletes Losing Out on Their Fair Share of Opportunities and Scholarships - Season 1 Episode 8

entry.content:
In this episode we spoke with Arthur Bryant, an attorney who has represented more women athletes and potential women athletes in Title IX litigation than any other lawyer in the country. We looked closely at the topic of women college athletes losing out on their fair share of opportunities and athletic scholarships as well as how Title IX can also apply to men athletes.

Co-Hosts: Evan Glotzer (SPME ‘23); Dustin Terry (SPME ‘23); Dr. Ellen J. Staurowsky

Guest: Arthur Bryant, J.D., an attorney with Bailey Glasser who has represented more women athletes and potential women athletes in Title IX litigation than any other lawyer in the country; he is chair emeritus of Public Justice, one of the nation’s leading public interest law firms; he received the Legacy Award from Public Justice in 2021; also the War Horse Award from the Southern Trial Lawyers Association in 2022 for his extraordinary contributions to the cause of justice; named a Sports Law Trailblazer by the National Law Journal in 2021

entry.title: Following the Bouncing Ball: Ways Schools Subvert the Intent of Title IX - Season 1 Episode 7

link.title: Following the Bouncing Ball: Ways Schools Subvert the Intent of Title IX - Season 1 Episode 7

entry.content:
In this episode we spoke with Kristen Galles, one of the nation’s most prominent Title IX litigators to learn more about how Title IX applies to athletic departments and to reflect on how, after 50 years since the passage of Title IX, athletic departments are slow to comply with Title IX.

Co-Hosts: Dean Gutic (SPME ‘23); Dr. Ellen J. Staurowsky

Guest: Kristin Galles, J.D., civil rights attorney and recipient of the 2022 Ramey Gender Justice Award; Kristen has been involved in many notable precedent setting Title IX cases such as Communities for Equity v. Michigan High School Athletic Association, Jackson v. Birmingham, Mansourian v. University of California Regents, Biediger v. Quinnipiac University, and Lazar v. UConn
